So, when you say only interfaces are visible (and I mean visibillity in s=
oftware programming sence) I understand all classes are not, so there is no=
 way to extend them (inherit). On the other hand, if classes are visible, t=
here is nothing preventing a client programmer instantiating these classes =
directly (not through interface). Generally, you will want to permit extend=
ing only certain classes.
The same thing happens on the method - field leve=
l, if you don't make method private, client programmer will consider it was=

OO. Rule No 1: encapsulate!
Only contract two progr=
ammers have to obey is code. What makes you think other programmer will rea=
d your docs or comments? But, if he tries to override private method, compi=
ler will not permit it. (Actually, he will not even know the method exist.)=
 
If you can ENFORCE something, you will not leave it to chance. Making met=
hod private or public is a design decision , not something arbitrary.
Leavi=
ng important information to comments, docs etc is extremely dangerous! I su=
ggest you check out refactoring catalogue www.refactoring.com ("Comments li=
e, code does not") and how refactoring community treats comments: either yo=
u don't need them  so you eliminate them or you make code out of them. Simi=
lar thing goes for documentation that is trying to explain code.
Making tes=
ting influence your design decision is an example of very testing-biased pa=
radigm, but this should not conflict with basic premises of OO, like most o=
f new usefull paradigms don't (for example AOP does not make you change OO =
principles, it builds on them).

pose of making methods private is to indicate that they are

class's API a better way is to encourage users of the

a Java Interface instead. When you make methods

 more difficult to test and short-circuits the
